item.title:
It's tempting to see @Base's success and to try and copy their strategy (modulo superficial branding)
The builder realizes that they will need to build a unique application to differentiate, and control the full-stack

item.title:
R to @KAndrewHuang: Our goal for Conduit is to reduce TCO by so much that even a free rollup platform would be a worse option.
Here are a few examples of how we do that.
item.dc:creator: @KAndrewHuang
item.description:
Our goal for Conduit is to reduce TCO by so much that even a free rollup platform would be a worse option.

Here are a few examples of how we do that.

item.title:
R to @KAndrewHuang: The best teams don‚Äôt look at rollup costs as a set of vendor line items.
They evaluate each piece of the rollup by its impact on total cost of operations. What do my infra choices cost not just in dollars, but in time, overhead, and opportunity?
item.dc:creator: @KAndrewHuang
item.description:
The best teams don‚Äôt look at rollup costs as a set of vendor line items.

They evaluate each piece of the rollup by its impact on total cost of operations. What do my infra choices cost not just in dollars, but in time, overhead, and opportunity?

item.title:
It doesn‚Äôt cost $10 million to launch a rollup.
But more importantly, you‚Äôre thinking about rollup costs all wrong.
Study Nvidia. Study Jensen Huang.
‚ÄúOur total cost of operations is so good that even when competitors‚Äô chips are free, it‚Äôs not cheap enough.‚Äù
item.dc:creator: @KAndrewHuang
item.description:
It doesn‚Äôt cost $10 million to launch a rollup.
